case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1718 of 1967 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 23-10-1964 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in First Appeal No. 89 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1718 of 1967 Appeal by special.leave from the judgment and Order dated 23-10-64 of the Allahabad High Court at  Lucknow Bench  in First Appeal No. 89 of 1957.

facts.text: The High Court reversed the decree for Rs. 11,000/- and passed a decree for Rs. 3,000/- with proportionate costs in favour of the appellant State.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decree for Rs. 1 1,000/- and passed a decree for a sum of Rs. 3,000/- with proportionate companyts in favour of the appellant State.

facts.text: The appellant is the proprietor of the reserved forest in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the proprietor of the reserved forest in Uttar Pradesh. The respondent took lease from the appellant of a plot of land at Chandan Chowki, Sonaripur Range in the North Kheri Forest Division at an annual rent of Rs. 1,000/-

facts.text: The respondent took lease from the appellant of a plot of land at Chandan Chowki, Sonaripur Range in the North Kheri Forest Division.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took lease from the appellant of a plot of land at Chandan Chowki, Sonaripur Range in the North Kheri Forest Division at an annual rent of Rs. 1,000/-

facts.text: The appellant granted a lease to the respondent for one year from 18 March 1947 at an annual rent of Rs. 100/-

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found these facts. The appellant had granted a lease to the respondent for one year from 18 March, 1947 at an annual rent of Rs. 100/-.

facts.text: The lease was renewed on 10 June 1948 with effect from 18 March 1948 for one year.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was renewed the following year on 10 June, 1948 with effect from 18 March, 1948 for one year. The lease was renewed again in 1949 for one year.

facts.text: The lease was renewed again in 1949 for one year and expired on 18 March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was renewed again in 1949 for one year. The lease expired on 18 March, 1950.

facts.text: After termination of the lease in March 1950, the respondent continued in possession and agreed to abide by terms to be fixed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: After the termination of the lease in March, 1949 the respondent companytinued to be in possession of the land and agreed to abide by the terms to be fixed by the appellant.

facts.text: Under terms fixed by appellant, respondent required to pay Rs. 1,000/- annual rent till 15 July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms fixed by the appellant the respondent was required to pay Rs. 1,000/- as annual rent, for the occupation of the land till 15 July, 1950.

facts.text: Respondent remained in possession after 15 July 1950; appellant allowed occupation for three years beyond that date.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent remained in possession of the leased property after the determination of the lease on 15 July, 1950. The appellant allowed the respondent to be in occupation for three years beyond 15 July, 1950.

facts.text: Respondent did not agree to any undertaking after 15 July 1950 like in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number agree to give any undertaking after 15 July, 1950 as in the year 1949 to agree to abide by the decision of the Government.

facts.text: On 27 August 1951, Forest Officer wrote to respondent for discussion on rent for 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: On 27 August, 1951 the Forest Officer of the- appellant wrote to the respondent for discussion regarding the rent for the year 1950-51.

facts.text: No evidence of any discussion on rent.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence as to whether there was any such discussion.

facts.text: On 4 December 1951, appellant's letter asked respondent to pay Rs. 3000/- for 1950-51 or Rs. 1800/- but no future lease.

anchor.surface_text: This is however a letter of the appellant dated 4 Decem ber, 1951 to the respondent where the respondent was asked to pay Rs. 3000/- for the year 1950-51 and if the respondent did number agree to pay the amount the rent would be reduced to Rs. 1800/- but the miff would number be allowed to have the lease in future in any circumstance.

facts.text: Respondent continued in occupation without agreement on rent for 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was allowed to companytinue in occupation of the land with- out any agreement as to the amount of rent payable for the year 1950-51.

facts.text: On 29 October 1952, Conservator sent notice offering lease terms or licensee status, demand Rs.6000/- damages.

anchor.surface_text: On 29 October, 1952 the Conservator of Forests on part of the appellant sent a numberice to the respondent that the appellant offered to allow the respondent to run the miff beyond 15 July, 1950 for three years provided the respondent paid Rs. 3000/- per annum and for one year only in case the respondent was prepared to pay Rs. 1800/- with the further companydition-that the lease would number be renewed.

facts.text: High Court concluded respondent continued in occupation with consent of appellant without agreement on rent.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts found by the High Court, the High Court companycluded that the respondent companytinued in occupation with the companysent of the appellant without any agreement as to the amount of rent or without any undertaking that the respondent would pay the rent fixed by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant assented to respondent continuing in possession after 15 July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, after the determination of the lease on 15 July, 1950 assented to the respondent companytinuing in possession.

facts.text: Lease was for industrial purposes, terminable by six months notice under section 106 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was for industrial purposes. Under the terms of section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act such lease is from year to year.

facts.text: No notice expiring with end of year of tenancy in 1952; tenancy continued.

anchor.surface_text: There was numbersuch numberice expiring with the end of a year of tenancy in 1952. The renewed tenancy therefore companytinued and was number terminated.

facts.text: High Court found rent payable Rs.1000/- per year as in 1949-50, decreed Rs.3000/- for three years 1950-51 to 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, companyrectly found that in the absence of any agreement to pay Rs. 3000/- as annual rent or in the absence of any agreement and undertaking that the respondent would accept the amount fixed by the appellant as the rent. The appellant was number entitled to anything more than Rs. 1000/- a year which was the amount of rent for the year 1949 to 1950.

facts.text: Lease for erecting temporary rice mill.

anchor.surface_text: The lease in the present case was for the purpose of erecting a temporary rice mill and for numberother purpose.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds High Court decree that respondent held over under section 116 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

issues.text: Whether the respondent's continuance in possession after the determination of the lease on 15 July 1950 with the assent of the appellant amounted to holding over and renewal of the lease from year to year under sections 106 and 116 of the Transfer of Property Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, after the determination of the lease on 15 July, 1950 assented to the respondent continuing in possession. The lease was for industrial purposes. Under the terms of section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act such lease is from year to year. Therefore, there being no agreement to the con

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was contended that the, provisions cc the Transfer of Property Act did number apply and therefore the respondent could number hold over within the meaning of section 116 of the transfer of Property Act. The State relied on the Government Grants Act.

issues.text: Whether the lease constituted a government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act such that TPA provisions are inapplicable

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that the State is the lessor will number by itself make it a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act. There is numberevidence in the present case in the character of the land or in the making of the lease of in the companytent of the lease to support the plea on behalf of the State that, it was a grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act.

Therefore, there being no agreement to the contrary the continuance by the respondent in possession of the leased premises amounted to renewal of the lease from 16 July, 1950 as a lease from year to year.

arguments.claim: Provisions of section 116 TPA applicable as in Lala Kishun Chand v. Sheo Dutta despite government land

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the present case relied on a Bench decision of that Court. That is the case of Lala Kishun Chand v. Sheo Dutta I.L.R. 1958 All. 879. The land in that case belonged to the Government and was nazul.

arguments.claim: Lease not a government grant like in Secretary of State v. Lal Mohan Chaudhuri; Khas Mahal lease not within GGA

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, there is an illustration of What is number a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act. The decision in Secretary of State for India in Council v. Lal Mohan Chaudhuri I.L.R. 63 Cal. 523 furnishes that illustration.

arguments.claim: Even if Government Grants Act applies, section 116 TPA not rendered inapplicable; construe grant as if TPA not passed but specific provisions apply unless contradicted

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Government Grants Act applied section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act was number rendered inapplicable. The effect of section 2 of the ,Government Grants Act is that in the construction of an instrument governed by the Government Grants Act the court shall construe such ,grant irrespective of the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act.

arguments.claim: Renewal of lease under section 116 means same terms and conditions as previous lease, including rent

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the amount of rent payable the provisions of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act indicate that the renewal of the lease would mean that the terms and conditions would be the same as of the previous lease.

arguments.claim: Respondent held over within meaning of section 116 TPA; High Court decree upheld

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

holdings.text: The respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant assented to respondent's continuance in possession after lease determination without agreement on rent; no proper termination notice; renewal on prior terms under ss 106 and 116 TPA; TPA applies notwithstanding GGA.

holdings.text: The lease is not a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act.

anchor.surface_text: The lease in the present case was for the purpose of erecting a temporary rice mill and for no other purpose. The mere fact that the State is the lessor will not by itself make it a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere fact that State is lessor insufficient; no evidence of land character, lease making, or intent supporting grant; distinguished from Sunderbans waste lands, analogous to Khas Mahal lease.

holdings.text: Even if the Government Grants Act applied, section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is not rendered inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Government Grants Act applied section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act was not rendered inapplicable. The effect of section 2 of the Government Grants Act is that in the construction of an instrument governed by the Government Grants Act the court shall construe such grant irrespective of the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: GGA s2 requires construction as if TPA not passed but does not exclude all TPA provisions; s116 operative unless contradicted by grant terms; Government retains unfettered discretion under s3 but specific rules like s116 apply; contrasts with s14 perpetuity rule.

holdings.text: There was no notice expiring with the end of a year of tenancy in 1952; the renewed tenancy continued and was not terminated.

anchor.surface_text: It would be a lease terminable by six months notice expiring with the end of the year of the tenancy. There was no such notice expiring with the end of a year of tenancy in 1952. The renewed tenancy therefore continued and was not terminated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s106 TPA, manufacturing lease terminable by six months notice expiring end of tenancy year; no compliant notice issued.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to more than Rs. 1000/- a year; renewal under section 116 on same terms as previous lease.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the amount of rent payable the provisions of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act indicate that the renewal of the lease would mean that the terms and conditions would be the same as of the previous lease. The High Court, therefore, correctly found that in the absence of any agreement to pay Rs. 3000/- as annual rent or in the absence of any agreement and undertaking that the respondent would accept the amount fixed by the appellant as the rent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No agreement to pay higher rent or abide by appellant's fixation; s116 renewal implies same terms and conditions including rent of Rs.1000/- from 1949-50.

holdings.text: Continuance in possession after lease determination with lessor's assent amounted to renewal from year to year under section 106 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, after the determination of the lease on 15 July, 1950 assented to the respondent continuing in possession. The lease was for industrial purposes. Under the terms of section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act such lease is from year to year. Therefore, there being no agreement to the contrary the continuance by the respondent in possession of the leased premises amounted to renewal of the lease from 16 July, 1950 as a lease from year to year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court facts show consent without rent agreement or undertaking; industrial lease year-to-year under s106; assent implies renewal.

precedents.case_name: Jnanendra Nath Nanda v Jadu Nath Banerji
precedents.cited_proposition: Example of a Government grant: leases of Sunderbans waste lands granted by Sunderban Commissioner on behalf of Secretary of State, vested in the Crown
precedents.cited_holding: Grants of Sunderbans lands vested in the Crown are Crown Grants within the meaning of the Crown Grants Act

precedents.citation: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Lal Mohan Chaudhuri I.L.R. 63 Cal. 523

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Lal Mohan Chaudhuri I.L.R. 63 Cal. 523

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v Lal Mohan Chaudhuri
precedents.cited_proposition: Illustration of what is not a Government grant: Government lease in respect of Khas Mahal lands
precedents.cited_holding: The lease of Khas Mahal was held not to fall within the category of grants as contemplated in the Crown Grants Act

precedents.citation: Lala Kishun Chand v. Sheo Dutta I.L.R. 1958 All. 879

anchor.surface_text: Lala Kishun Chand v. Sheo Dutta I.L.R. 1958 All. 879

precedents.case_name: Lala Kishun Chand v Sheo Dutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Lessee of government nazul land continuing in possession after lease expiry with permission of lessor amounts to holding over under section 116 of Transfer of Property Act; section 2 of Government Grants Act does not render Transfer of Property Act inapplicable
precedents.cited_holding: The lessee remained in possession after termination of lease and therefore there was holding over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act; contention that section 2 of Government Grants Act rendered Transfer of Property Act inapplicable not accepted

anchor.surface_text: The lease in the present case was for the purpose of erecting a temporary rice mill and for no other purpose. The mere fact that the State is the lessor will not by itself make it a Government grant within the meaning of the Government Grants Act.
For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Government Grants Act applied section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act was not rendered inapplicable. The effect of section 2 of the Government Grants Act is that in the construction of an instrument governed by the Government Grants Act the court shall construe such grant irrespective of the provisions of the Transfer of Property Act.
For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: It would be a lease terminable by six months notice expiring with the end of the year of the tenancy. There was no such notice expiring with the end of a year of tenancy in 1952. The renewed tenancy therefore continued and was not terminated.
For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the amount of rent payable the provisions of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act indicate that the renewal of the lease would mean that the terms and conditions would be the same as of the previous lease. The High Court, therefore, correctly found that in the absence of any agreement to pay Rs. 3000/- as annual rent or in the absence of any agreement and undertaking that the respondent would accept the amount fixed by the appellant as the rent.
For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, therefore, after the determination of the lease on 15 July, 1950 assented to the respondent continuing in possession. The lease was for industrial purposes. Under the terms of section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act such lease is from year to year. Therefore, there being no agreement to the contrary the continuance by the respondent in possession of the leased premises amounted to renewal of the lease from 16 July, 1950 as a lease from year to year.
For these reasons the decree of the High Court that the respondent held over within the meaning of section 116 of the Transfer of Property Act is upheld.
